1: Read all .txt files in the documents folder, analyze the sentiment of each, create a comparison report showing which documents are most positive vs negative, and email the report to manager@company.com
2: Scan every .txt in the documents directory, run sentiment analysis, rank them from most positive to most negative, and email the comparison report to manager@company.com
3: Go through all .txt files under documents, score their sentiment, compile a summary that contrasts the happiest vs most critical files, and send it by email to manager@company.com
4: Analyze sentiment for each .txt file in the documents folder, highlight the top positive and top negative entries, and email the findings report to manager@company.com
5: Perform sentiment scoring on all documents/*.txt files, build a side-by-side report of the most upbeat versus most negative documents, and email that report to manager@company.com
6: Read every text file in documents, compute sentiment, produce a comparative chart of positive versus negative documents, and email it to manager@company.com
7: Collect all .txt files from the documents folder, evaluate their sentiment, list which are most positive and most negative, and email the comparison to manager@company.com
8: Process documents/*.txt for sentiment, summarize which files are strongly positive or negative, and email the report to manager@company.com
9: Run sentiment analysis across all .txt files in documents, rank them from positive to negative, and email the ranking report to manager@company.com
10: Inspect each .txt in the documents folder, score sentiment, create a brief report contrasting the most positive vs most negative documents, and email it to manager@company.com
